data.title: "Error: Map contains invalid custom rules." hides the linter error
data.body: It only says `OpenRA.Utility(1,1): Error: Map contains invalid custom rules.` instead of pointing to what actually failed. I first really noticed it during #13934, where Monster Tank Madness just gave this not helpful at all error, because a required field (`IntoActor`) wasn't set for `5tnk.husk`. I believe it is also one of the reasons for bad performance of the lint checks. The ones during ruleset loading are at least conflicting and probably even duplicating the effort making it way too expensive.

data.title: Allow engineers to repair damaged bridges.
data.body:
Currently not possible. You need to first destroy it before you can repair it to full.

Broken bridges slows down vehicle movement. Allowing the player to repair bridges with the engineer would be a nice detail for maps that use broken bridges for various effects.

data.title: Fix compile error in CommandBarLogic.
data.body: Fixes regression / implicit rebase conflict between #13974 and #14010.

data.title: [TD request] Display a visual warning of an air strike or a nuke (optional)
data.body:
Various players (myself included) have reported not hearing EVA warn of an airstrike or a nuke in TD, preventing the player from taking evasive action. I suspect that occurs when a lot is going on and the audio channels get 'maxed out' (I seem to experience it during a battle, though air strikes are often called then anyway). This is not new, having been experienced over a good few releases.

I suggest we have the option of displaying a visual (textual) warning when an enemy airstrike is called or an enemy nuke is launched. That would also help those playing without sound (either by choice, necessity, physical impairment, or when the sound bugs out - as happens to me on occasion). 

If adopted, perhaps it could be on by default (to help newer players), but with the option to turn it off in the menu.

data.title: Add InitialDelay to CashTrickler and add CashTricklerBar
data.body: Fixes  #14022 and also adds a CashTricklerBar trait.

data.title: Fix AI BuildingLimits
data.body:
The AI BaseBuilder would allow building a structure not only when the current number was lower, but also if it was *equal* to the limit, which allowed the AI to build one too many of every building with a build limit.

This is a simple and obvious enough fix to sneak into stable.

Closes #11917.

data.title: AI BuildingLimit doesn't limit anything
data.body:
The **AI happily ignores building limits.** In Dune2k every production structure and all tech structures are set to max 1. Despite that the AI builds 1,2 or 3 repair pads, 2 warfactories, 5 refineries, multiple outposts etc...
![bug_buildinglimit3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16046997/30487360-8c24cdc0-9a33-11e7-9e3f-060e4b4ec996.png)

On units the limit seems to work.

Also, the limit should imply **all transformations** of a unit. So, if I say MCV: 1 the AI should build one mcv ONLY if it hasn't a conyard allready. As of now the AI builds one mcv, deploys it and then builds another one... -.-
That would also require new errors if two conflicting limits are set. (MCV=1, Conyard=3)

data.title: Rename some turret-related render traits
data.body:
Split from #13619, as the uninterruptability part might need some more work and time.

Carrying over the +1 from @abcdefg30 since this part is uncontroversial, I think.

data.title: CashTrickler don't have an initial delay before giving first cash
data.body:
It is not really important for our oil derricks as they are preplaced, owned by neutral, but it would make a difference for a buildable actor, especially if used with high amount and intervals.

I already wrote an optional fix (an InitialDelay value for CashTrickler) locally, but probably can't file a PR today. Opening this issue for now.

data.title: Remove EjectOnDeath from RA Vehicles
data.body: Closes #14020

data.title: Decide whether to keep EjectOnDeath on RA vehicles
data.body:
#13892 had an unintentional side-effect of fixing an old, long broken and forgotten feature in the RA mod to spawn infantry from destroyed vehicles. 

If we want to keep this "new" feature then it should be listed in the Changelog.  If not, then `EjectOnDeath` should be removed from the `^Vehicle` default.

Related IRC discussion / initial report: https://logs.openra.net/?year=2017&month=09&day=11#23:10:07

data.title: Bug report : repair burned friend mcv and get friend unit abilities
data.body:
in multiplayer 2v2 game one of enemies build mcv and send that to his friend base
allied person explode friend soviet mcv and repair that with mechanic and get new mcv with soviet abilities!!!
after that allied person can build IC and Tesla and soviet building & units & superpowers !!!!
its really bad bug and after i see this in game i surrend because i cant win this unfare game!!!
replay attached here  : 
[OpenRA-2017-09-12T151523Z.orarep.zip](https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/files/1299820/OpenRA-2017-09-12T151523Z.orarep.zip)

data.title: Being able to toggle on savings (and assets?) of a player in the earnings graph
data.body:
Under the stat-button we have the earning section, which has the earnings during the game displayed.
It's interesting to also see the amount of savings (and assets?) a player had during the course of the game.
Perhaps the user can toggle those on/off to display them in the graph. 
Assets would perhaps be a little annoying as their value usually outgrows the income/min and savings values, which would result in those graphs barely being visible.

Here's an ugly mock up I've made with the savings 'turned on' (gave them a darker shade of the player's colour)

Normal earnings graph
![normal](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13763434/30376402-85f78742-988c-11e7-9f2e-bf726607b8bd.png)

graph with savings ticked on
![savings](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13763434/30376403-85ff73f8-988c-11e7-8449-18f8e9f09601.png)

data.title: Fix music stopping
data.body:
Fixes #13763.

This PR removes audio streaming, in order to avoid the bugs that seem to be cropping up from the playtests.

We now load and play music all at once, but we do keep some of the benefits of the original PR:
- We load the sound in a background task, avoiding the UI locking up for a couple of seconds. Instead, the game keeps running and there is merely a couple of seconds silence whilst the next track loads.
- Music is still no longer cached, preventing the music tracks from eating up all your memory.

Hopefully this means we get most of the gains without most of the bugs!

data.title: [RA Map Pool] Replace map Agenda with Bandit.
data.body:
map uploaded at: http://resource.openra.net/maps/22791/

As mentioned on https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/13972#issuecomment-326791653 and on IRC:

We might want to replace Agenda with a more subtle map for the release. Agenda was initially the only map that reliably showcased all the civilian structures but ideally we might want a map that doesn't throw the player out on a huge and heavily competitive map. Map 'Bandit' is less intimidating in that fashion and plays well too.

data.title: Transports are moving over ground
data.body:
![beachbug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21260178/30251391-ea219418-965e-11e7-990c-28c974c592d0.gif)

The tiles are 28 and 9.

data.title: Option to disable cosmetic renderings
data.body:
Tiberian Sun had a detail level option in-game.
See http://modenc.renegadeprojects.com/Detail_Level_System for reference.

We could also tag some `WithIdleOverlay` or `Contrail` with something similar and avoid drawing it to save some resources on low end systems. I don't know if this has a lot of impact.

data.title: Add "Assault Move" modifier to attack move
data.body:
As discussed in other tickets, IRC, and on the forum.  This follows the lead from C&C3 in providing an a quick and stateless attack-anything + attack move variation.

This also fixes autotargeting vs buildings in TS, and adds an attack-move cursor to d2k (in addition to assault-move cursors for RA and TD).  The second commit will need to be edited to work with the older hotkey setup when picking to prep.

Closes #14008

data.title: Allow vehicles to fire while moving
data.body: Most of explaining is in [this thread](http://www.sleipnirstuff.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=82&t=20242)

data.title: Toggle/switch for "attack non-combat buildings"
data.body:
A lot of words has already been said on it, so I just want to bring it to the github plane.

Looks like a new A-move modifier will be introduced in the next playtest (ctrl a-move), allowing the old attack behaviour when army attacks all units and buildings. [here](http://www.sleipnirstuff.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=82&p=304663#304663) @pchote mentions that it's quite a lot of work to make it a toggle rather than modifier.

Still, we think this feature should be considered to be made as a toggle in the future, even if not for the upcoming release. All the details on the suggestion can be read [here](http://www.sleipnirstuff.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=82&p=303590#303590).

data.title: Remove dummy d2k support bin overlay.
data.body:
Fixes #13999.

D2K doesn't draw an overlay over the support power icons, but was set up to draw a transparent image instead of simply removing the overlay yaml.  As of #13552, that space was no longer transparent.

data.title: Calculate building placement offsets in screen space
data.body:
PBOG and the editor actor brush need to solve the problem of "find the cell that places the center of the actor preview closest to the mouse position".  This is currently done by finding the cell under the mouse and then adding a world space offset, but this doesn't work as well as it could, especially with even-sides buildings, is implemented subtly wrong (#14000), and is completely bogus when terrain height is a factor.

Doing this in screen space is cleaner and gives better results.

Fixes #14000
Fixes #13985

data.title: Always use noget in fetch-thirdparty-deps-windows.sh
data.body: This is #13912 but for Windows builds.

data.title: Add RescanWhileNotMoving to AttackFollow
data.body: This is needed to stop following the current target if it isn't targetable any more. I made it optional because it isn't needed in most cases and has a potential performance hit.

data.title: Paratroopers should notify player when they land
data.body:
Players will often forget paratroopers after they call in a drop as planes may take a long time to arrived after the order has been issued. This is frustrating for not just players but spectators as well as paratroopers may go unused for several minutes. 

Players should be notified when the drop reaches the LZ by the ReinforcementsArrived notification.

IIRC this is also true to the original.

data.title: Linter error? Or error editing/making shps?
data.body:
Hi, 
I have been killing all linter errors I could find in my maps, like Chrisf suggested (by rolling eyes at me ignoring lint checks).

But this last one I don't grasp, pchote suggested I file it here...
It first appeared when I added custom shp's to my map. Anyone has an Idea what this might have caused? Keep in mind that I was using a mash-up of editing tools including gimp, os shp builder and XCC utilities to generate those shps, so there might be some error there as well.
However, the map (and all of its successors) runs without crashes, afaik.

```
Testing map: [VS.mis] Atreides Mission 1
OpenRA.Utility(1,1): Error: OpenRA.Mods.Common.Lint.CheckSequences failed with exception: System.NullReferenceException: Der Objektverweis wurde nicht auf eine Objektinstanz festgelegt.
   bei OpenRA.Mods.Common.Lint.CheckSequences.<CheckDefintions>c__AnonStorey6.<>m__0(MiniYamlNode n)
   bei System.Linq.Enumerable.FirstOrDefault[TSource](IEnumerable`1 source, Func`2 predicate)
   bei OpenRA.Mods.Common.Lint.CheckSequences.CheckDefintions(String image, SequenceReferenceAttribute sequenceReference, KeyValuePair`2 actorInfo, String sequence, String faction, FieldInfo field, ITraitInfo traitInfo)
   bei OpenRA.Mods.Common.Lint.CheckSequences.Run(Action`1 emitError, Action`1 emitWarning, Map map)
   bei OpenRA.Mods.Common.UtilityCommands.CheckYaml.OpenRA.IUtilityCommand.Run(Utility utility, String[] args)
```
Map where this first occurs: http://resource.openra.net/maps/20201

data.title: [RA] Isolate new auto targeting vs structures towards Return Fire/Hold Fire
data.body:
I wanted to wait on this issue ticket until a later time with this playtest cycle as I hoped more players would have the experience with the unit stances, particularly the broader community affiliated with big team games, which represents the bedrock of the online and multiplayer community. Unfortunately as with every previous playtest cycle in the past this particular sector won't have much exposure of the mod's changes, if any at all, until the offial release has been shipped. In contrast with most previous releases however, the RA mod has with it planned features that for the most part carry no real foresight as to how it will be experienced by the broader community, leaving most the discussion left to guesswork.

The last time we had a halfway similar event was with release 2013.12.23 with the introduction of the 16c0  Con.Yard build radius. For most people this change came aboard with minimal preparation but still it was anticipated as there was a strong demand to curb infinite basewalking for a long period of time. https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/issues/2156

The problem and potential pitfall that _I_ see with the auto targeting is pretty simple and has nothing to do with balancing, unit control or anything like that. As I see it, the totality of the negative side of the feature's effect experienced by the players within the RA mod will _by far_ come from the silent majority – the casual online playerbase, for the most part frequently tied up with massive team games and players off-line content with playing against the A.I. The changing back and forth, on and off the "building-attack-stance" (these players have absolutely no interest in 'Defensive' vs 'Attack Anything' behavior) is how it's gonna translate in the mind of these particular lot of players. A prerequisite game mechanic to be executed in order to finish off an enemy and close out the game. This issue get's wildly proportional with the increasing number of enemies and for the online team games you have by default scenarios with great amount of units swarming through huge fields of buildings waiting to be turned on by the player only to have it be done again with the next wave of units and/or with the next move should the player decide to switch back to the default stance. The constant going back to the command bar or using hotkeys to execute these commands is a simple matter to the prominent named community members but for the pool of players actually keeping OpenRA alive it's gonna be a whole different ballgame.

Besides the implementation from a simple technical standpoint you also have the visual side of it where you'll see a big group of units suddenly "turns on" and starts shooting at every building around them in a quasi-synchronized way per unit-type.

Having players adapt to new features with new ways to control units is something I believe I understand to a certain degree and I do absolutely understand the sentiment of requiring players to learn new sets of tools to further a positive agenda but in this particular case I believe very strongly the response will be that of disappointment once the reality of the feature kicks in with the above described scenarios, which according to my guesstimate represents over 90% of how the RA mod is experienced by the totality of RA's playerbase. It's simply just not user friendly and for many of these players, who don't give a second thought about ref placements, build-orders, micro or executing advanced strategy, just won't understand the added inconvenience seemingly coming out of nowhere for reasons they won't understand. Not because they're disinterested in the game's development but simply because it directly put's a wedge in-between the players and them having plain _simple_ fun – and I emphasize 'simple' because as of now there's an excellent 'flat scale' ranging from experiencing the game from the most basic level to the smaller core of expert players taking advantage of game mechanics unavailable to new players, simply because of level of skill. In my view the foundational 'simple' is the first step and sole reason for why most people are coming on to OpenRA and in many cases play the mods endlessly to eventually becoming a part of an active community.

The feature cuts deep into the identity of the OpenRA project itself, constantly struggling to join two polar opposites which conserves the spirit of the archaic C&C Red Alert versus improvements brought on board from its successors. Every deviation has its existence ideally rooted in necessity of making the game fun and playable with emphasis on skirmish and by extension, the online multiplayer mode. If we wanted to experience the original as-is, particularly the campaigns, we only have to look towards the abandon-ware. The 'avoid-targeting-buildings' stance emulates the experience drawn from the original game where you could overcome the enemy with your forces, camp its base and take over all the buildings with your engineer. In fact, growing up with this game, I did this religiously with every mission just for the role-play of utterly dominating and humiliating the enemy and if possible, beat them with their own units. It was certainly a fond part of the original game but as-is this game mechanic doesn't translate well over to the RA mod's skirmish. The mod now having availed almost every game asset to the player, popularized online multiplayer and "inflated" the game to enormous levels when it comes to the count of units and structures in any given game, particularly big team games, fully eclipses the role of the original targeting to the point where it lines up with other archaic features that made sense at the time but currently just serve to limit the experience.

The above point simply never came across properly in the feature's playtest discussion, one root reason being that the game almost exclusively is being analysed publicly from a competitive viewpoint. Usually there's an approach from both sides that eventually falls on a solution that everyone can relate to. Granted, regarding balancing I've been a sort of rogue mediator the past two  release cycles but for other feature related changes, AFAIK there are very few implementations that fell short with the playing community. In this particular case the discussion was also polarized right off the bat and a clear-headed discussion about what that change would mean for the game as a whole was simply not possible. 

The juicy reward following this feature makes itself evident in the mods' campaigns. I had a run through with the RA playtest campaign missions and it's definately an added 'blast from the past' experience with camping the AI in order to gain yourself a new base with the enemy tech but it also underscores why the feature can be expected to work differently for the missions vs skirmish as the mission A.I. bases are usually both limited and static. For the missions there's a very strong argument for bringing this feature onboard but the question also then falls on wether or not to formalize the feature across all play modes as the gamerules deviation between the missions and skirmish are currently very few and with every addition to that list would be a noticeable step in widening the gap between the two game modes.

The idea proposed as mentioned in the title would have the 'no-targeting-buildings' left for the ReturnFire/HoldFire stances, meaning it's a feature the player turns _on_ in order to wipe out everything except unarmed buildings. Specifically, A-moving with AttackAnything/Defensive would target everything in its path as default but with ReturnFire/HoldFire would target only units and defensive structures, making way of a potential take-over with engineers or just for plain old fun, if wanted. The point is this feature from that point is an addition, enriching the experience in a way that would immediately be beneficial for both missions _and_ casual/competitive play. It also falls neatly within the stance categories with a two-for-two and for any concerns regarding unwanted side-effects with AttackAnything vs Defense stance, would be gone.

One important thing pointed out about this feature is that it's been in the works for a very long time, with an early attempt to include the feature in 2013 (#3337) but because of issues with the A.I. it was shelved until the surrounding issues was resolved. Couple the hard work of making the feature possible with the stated development goals for OpenRA it should follow that this feature makes its way into OpenRA's flagship mod. However it's my conviction the feature would be celebrated as a feature added on top of the current workings of the game, providing a link back to the original game for the missions and an exiting tool for players to explore with both skirmish and online multiplayer.
